Hello,

since i cannot post to the google group, i raise this here. It is not really a bug.
I think the exporters (at least for gcc arm) can be improved by using template inheritance from jinja2: http://jinja.pocoo.org/docs/templates/#template-inheritance

I did a very rough sample implementation for four exporters:
https://github.com/chrta/mbed/compare/exporter_template_refactoring

What do you think?

title: Recover from exception in serial.sendBreak() in linux.
body:
When i execute the script workspace_tools/make.py to execute a test on my lpcxpresso1549 board, an exception is raised on line https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/blob/master/workspace_tools/make.py#L189 in serial.sendBreak().

Linux: Fedora 20 kernel 3.14.7-200.fc20.x86_64
Python: 2.7.5

Currently this is only tested in fedora 20 and with the lpcxpresso1549.
I can test it in a week on the LPC1768 board.

See mbedmicro/mbed#362

title: Script workspace_tools/make.py crashes in linux in serial.sendBreak()
body:
When i execute the script workspace_tools/make.py to execute a test on my lpcxpresso1549 board, an exception is raised on line https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/blob/master/workspace_tools/make.py#L189 in serial.sendBreak().

Linux: Fedora 20 kernel 3.14.7-200.fc20.x86_64
Python: 2.7.5

When i replace the line serial.sendBreak() with the following code, it works fine:

``` python
           try:
                serial.sendBreak()
            except:
                # In linux a termios.error is raised in sendBreak and in setBreak.
                # The following setBreak() is needed to release the reset signal on the target mcu.
                try:
                    serial.setBreak(False)
                except:
                    pass
```

title: Add support for remote CAN frames on LPC11CXX
body:
- Fixed bug where outgoing messages always had `DIR` bit set, even if message type was `CANRemote`.
- Fixed TODO where incoming messages were always assigned message type `CANData` even if the message was remote
- Changed filter setup to no longer set `MDIR` bit in receive filter; this allows remote messages to pass through the filter.

I've tested this on an LPC11C14 and seems to work fine. The one caveat is that the filter no longer prevents remote messages from showing up in `CAN.read()` (though the message type is now set correctly). I'm not sure what the default behavior for filtering data vs remote frames on other platforms is right now.

Perhaps the filter API should include an enum for filtering message of type CANData vs CANRemote vs either.

title: LPC11U68 AnalogIn Extremely Slow
[LPC1549] Fixed potential build error by GCC
mbed serial readable() seeing all bytes
body:
Hello,

I have used mbed on and off for several years without having any issues with the serial port. Recently I started using a IC that has a UART output (Silabs si8900).When powered has an auto baud function that happens were you send a single byte until it can match the baud and send a single byte response . I have no trouble receiving and reading the single character during auto baud, only when I try to read the 3 byte response during normal use does it appear to not read the 2nd and 3rd byte.

Below is an image showing what is going on. 

The top section of code shows my read statement which picks bytes from the buffer while readable() returns 1. The 3 byte response comes after I send a request byte, which is not shown. 

The middle section shows the values during debugging which shows I read the first byte but shows no values stored in the other bytes due to readable() returning 0.

The third section is the logic analyzer output showing the 3 byte response.

![readlineissue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2984346/3160892/404cda06-eb26-11e3-8d14-48e9be2a08ea.png)

The only thing I can think of is there is no delay between bytes and the serial port might see it as a single byte with framing issues. I do not know enough about the serial port library to know what could be causing this issue. It would be helpful if somebody could take a look at this and see if they can find anything.

As a side note, I programmed simple software serial functions but due to how quickly the response is from the IC the timing does not work out well.

Any help would be appreciated.

title: NRF51822 gcc arm export
body:
@0xc0170 

What follows is my description of the work I've done in order have a GCC_ARM exporter for the nRF51822 target board.  I'm able to successfully export the test export project, unzip it, and run make without any errors.  The .bin file created after running make doesn't seem to do anything once flashed on the device, so there's obviously something wrong (probably many many other things wrong as well), but the work so far should be a good starting point in order to get this exporter out to the public.
I welcome any input, recommendations, and tips.  
I hadn't heard of the word 'mbed' until 2 weeks ago, I received my nRF51822-mbed kit 3 days ago, so I'm very very new to all this, but I'm a professional python developer by day, and a hobbyist embedded developer at night.  It's been quite wonderful working with the python tooling around this project, and it's the only way I could have gotten this far in such a small amount of time.
Anyway, onto the description of my work so far....

On ubuntu 14.04, do the following, otherwise probably skip this step
Install gcc-arm-none-eabi v4.7.4 from here:  https://launchpadlibrarian.net/151487636/gcc-arm-none-eabi-4_7-2013q3-20130916-linux.tar.bz2
The default gcc included in the ubuntu 14.04 repo is 4.8, and does not include nano.specs files needed for compiling.

Add 'GCC_ARM' to NRF51822 supported_toolchains in workspace_tools/targets.py
Build toolchain: python workspace_tools/build.py -m NRF51822 -t GCC_ARM
Looks like it built successfully

Run the basic test:
python workspace_tools/make.py -m NRF51822 -t GCC_ARM -p 0 -v
Looks like it compiles successfully, but linking fails because linker file does not exist

You can see GCC linker scripts in the official SDK from Nordic.
Copy sdk/nrf51822/Source/templates/gcc/gcc_nrf51_blank_xxaa.ld to libraries/mbed/targets/cmsis/TARGET_NORDIC/TARGET_NRF51822/TOOLCHAIN_GCC_ARM/NRF51822.ld 
- 'blank', because I'll worry about adding BLE softdevice later.  I'm just trying to get the most basic thing working. 
- 'xaaa' because that's the 256kb of the chip used in the nrf51822-mbed kit.

Also, don't forget to copy sdk/nrf51822/Source/templates/gcc/gcc_nrf51_common.ld to libraries/mbed/targets/cmsis/TARGET_NORDIC/TARGET_NRF51822/TOOLCHAIN_GCC_ARM/gcc_nrf51_common.ld

Delete build/ and run build.py and make.py again, and it looks like that worked.   basic.bin file created.  Auto flashing/copying .bin to mass storage device failed because it's looking for a .hex file instead.  I added a check to NRF51822 Target, and if the toolchain is GCC_ARM, it sets the OUTPUT_EXT to .bin

At this point you can compile, but the resulting .bin file doesn't seem to do anything when flashed to the device.  I think you need to convert .bin to intel .hex, and probably lots more.

Now I want to get the export 'working'

Add ('gcc_arm', 'NRF51822') to workspace_tools/export_test.py
Run workspace_tools/export_test.py, and notice that it says that NRF51822 is not supported by the toolchain

Add 'NRF51822' to TARGETS list in workspace_tools/export/gccarm.py  run export tests again, and now it'll complain that workspace_tools/export/gcc_arm_nrf51822.tmpl file is missing

Copy workspace_tools/export/gcc_arm_kl25z.tmpl to workspace_tools/export/gcc_arm_nrf51822.tmpl, and change the mcpu from 'cortex-m0plus' to 'cortex-m0'
Now after running the export test again, there will be a build/export/export_gcc_arm_NRF51822.zip file.  SUCCESS.

You can extract this file, and run make, but you'll get a bunch of errors because of some things we haven't taken care of yet.

The test export project seems to use the RTOS library, and that's where most of the errors are coming from.

First fix the missing #defines because of undefined targets #ifndefs in rtos/rtx/RTX_Conf_CM.c
I've no idea if these numbers are correct, but I've added checks for TARGET_NRF51822 which sets the following:
- Make OS_TASKCNT 14
- Make OS_SCHEDULERSTKSIZE 256
- Make OS_CLOCK 16000000  (not sure if it's supposed to be this, or 32768000)

Delete build/export, run export tests again, extract zip, run make, and notice the RTX_Conf_CM.c errors are gone.  

Now take care of the errors in RTX_CM_lib.h.  Define INITIAL_SP to 0x20004000UL.  No idea if that's correct, but I found it googling somewhere, I can't remember.

Again, delete build/export, run export tests again, extract zip, run make, and notice the RTX_CM_lib.h errors are gone, and this time the compilation takes a bit longer than before because it's actually able to compile rtos library.  But you'll notice that there's a warning about not being able to find the symbol Reset_Handler.  That's because we're missing a startup file where those are defined.

Nordic makes startup files available in their official SDK.  Copy sdk/nrf51822/Source/templates/gcc/gcc_startup_nrf51.s to libraries/mbed/targes/cmsis/TARGET_NORDIC/TARGET_NRF51822/TOOLCHAIN_GCC_ARM/startup_NRF51822.s

Delete everything in build , run build, run export tests, extract zip, run make, and notice that a .bin file is created.  SUCCESS.
Flashing that .bin doesn't do anything, and the compilation gave warnings about memory region FLASH and RAM not being declared in gcc_nrf51_common.ld script, even though they're defined in NRF51822.ld

Merge NRF51822.ld and gcc_nrf51_common.ld into a single NRF51822.ld file, so those warnings go away.

Still the .bin doesn't seem to do anything when flashed to the device, but at least something is being exported, and what's exported can be compiled and linked without any errors.

title: [NUCLEO_F103RB] and [NUCLEO_F401RE] add SPI slave and I2C slave
increase timeout for slow I2C slaves that make use of extensive clock stretching
Ensure the NVIC table gets copied to RAM even when it is not at 0x0000
body:
When using user application code on an actual mbed the original code runs fine. 

However, when migrating from a prototype to a bare metal controller that is running on a circuit designed from scratch you typically implement a secondary boot loader that enables updating the flash from USB or from an SD card. This secondary bootloader requires that you compile the mbed-based application code with an offset. Before jumping to the application the SCB->VTOR register is set to the correct offset for the vector table in the application code (in flash).

Here lies the catch: the mbed startup code checks if the SCB->VTOR == 0x0000 and if it is not the case it does not copy the vector table to RAM. It also tries to adapt the table, which is not possible (the application cannot write to the flash memory).

With the proposed fix the code runs fine with or without a bootloader.

title: LPC11UXX & LPC11U6X I2C Fast-mode Plus Support
body: I'd like to run the I2C bus on the LPC11U35 and LPC11U68 at 1MHz (Fast-mode Plus), but the current implementation of _i2c_api.c_ does not configure the I2C mode on PIO0_4 and PIO0_5. In fact, _pinmap.c_ doesn't provide a way to specify the I2C mode at all. According to both datasheets, the mode needs to be set using bits 8 and 9 in the PIO0_4 and PIO0_5 IOCON registers.

title: Fix reset glitch in pwmout_write()
body:
Resetting the timer every time the duty cycle is changed causes unwanted glitches to be produced on the output. These glitches manifest as a tone at the update frequency when PWM is used for class D style audio.

NOTE: pwmout_pulsewidth_us() might suffer from the same issue, but I have no way of testing it to make sure.

title: I2C byte read fix for Freescale platforms
body:
Single byte reads did not correctly ACK/NACK, that should be fixed with this.

K64F platform is untested, I don't expect issues, but needs a test :). Old code will by normal usage never reads with NACK, now it should correctly NACK the last byte (assuming of course you tell it to send a NACK). Or without logic analyzer, try this code: https://mbed.org/questions/3181/Inconsistent-results-when-attempting-wri/. If that works it should be fixed.

It also tells me the branches cannot be automatically merged. I don't know how I can see what the issue is, neither how I can fix it, so have fun ;).

Erik
